In the literature, GQD and another kind of 0D carbon materials (carbon dot) are often not carefully distinguished. Here, we would like to stress that GQDs and carbon dots (CDs) differ in morphology and properties. CDs are spherical carbon particles. Some are completely amorphous sp3 carbon while some have a crystalline sp2 core encapsulated by an amorphous shell. Typically, the diameter of a CD is >3 nm, and CDs have a relatively wide
X-ray diffraction (XRD) peak due to the presence of amorphous carbon. Also, unlike GQDs the completely amorphous CDs do not present crystalline lattice under high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM). Furthermore, the electronic bandgap structures of GQDs are largely influenced by quantum confinement effect[4] whereas CDs’ bandgap structures are dictated by the surface energy traps. Due to these differences, some methods or applications work well for one but may not work well for the other. Although GQDs and CDs share some similarities, here we exclusively focus on the former.
0D quantum dots can also be derived from other 2D materials (notably, transition metal dichalcogenides).[1] These 2D materials range from insulators (e.g., h-BN and HfS2), large bandgap semiconductors (e.g., C3N4, MoS2, and WS2), small bandgap semiconductors (e.g., black phosphorene), and metallike conductors (e.g., VSe2). In comparison to GQDs, QDs derived from these 2D materials have distinct intrinsic electronic structures, thickness, and other properties. Some of them can fluoresce in the visible light range for biomedical imaging (e.g., MoS2 QD), but they are not very stable and dispersible in aqueous solution, not easily to be functionalized, or has very low photoluminescence quantum yield (QY).
Pristine GQD is rarely useful other than for electronic devices. And it cannot be easily synthesized and dispersed. In fact, it is chemical groups, functionalized groups, defects, dopants, and their coexistence that make GQDs interesting and versatile. But one may argue that the conductivity (an intrinsic merit of graphene) is lost due to these factors. This is indeed the case and some papers mistakenly claim that their device or electrode performance is benefited from the good conductivity of GQDs. Although the conductivity (laterally through the basal plane) is compromised, many studies have shown that GQDs
Graphene quantum dots (GQDs) that are flat 0D nanomaterials have attracted increasing interest because of their exceptional chemicophysical properties and novel applications in energy conversion and storage, electro/photo/chemical catalysis, flexible devices, sensing, display, imaging, and theranostics. The significant advances in the recent years are summarized with comparative and balanced discussion. The differences between GQDs and other nanomaterials, including their nanocarbon cousins, are emphasized, and the unique advantages of GQDs for specific applications are highlighted. The current challenges and outlook of this growing field are also discussed.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Graphene quantum dot (GQD) is the latest addition to the nanocarbon materials family. It is a 0D graphene material, characterized by an atomically thin graphitic plane (typically 1 or 2 layers, <2 nm thick) with lateral dimensions typically <10 nm. Comparing to its 2D counterpart, graphene sheet, GQD offers some unique merits thus new application opportunities, such as, bandgap opening due to quantum confinement, excellent dispersibility, more abundant active sites (edges, functional groups, dopants, etc.), better tunability in chemicophysical properties, and comparable size to biomolecules.[1–3]
Some may regard GQD merely as a giant polyaromatic molecule. But comparing to polycyclic aromatic molecules (e.g., pyrene), GQD has distinct and much more intriguing

There are already a number of excellent review articles on graphene quantum dots.[2,3,7] For example, we have provided a comprehensive review on the biological applications of GQDs in 2015.[2] Since then, some new exciting developments have been demonstrated, including imaging dynamic cellular processes, in vivo imaging, new design schemes for sensitive fluorescence-based detection, and therapeutic applications. There are also new dimensions that have been added to energy and catalysis applications, including novel GQD-based heterojunctions, GQDs as quasihomogeneous catalysis for chemical conversion, and GQDs with intramolecular Z-scheme for photocatalysis. As the field is rapidly evolving, periodic update is necessary. Here we emphasize on the latest significant developments on synthesis, property control, and unique applications in energy conversion and storage, catalysis, flexible devices, and biotechnology (Figure 1). We endeavor to offer comparative and balanced views, as well as insights into why GQDs are particularly advantageous for specific applications. Lastly, the current challenges and outlook of this area are provided.

sections.heading: 2. Synthesis
sections.text: The synthetic strategies of GQDs are based on either cutting the larger graphitized carbon materials (top-down) or the fusion of small precursor molecules (bottom-up). The topdown methods involve oxidative cutting,[8] reductive cutting,[9] physical grinding,[10] or combination of grinding and cutting.[11] The first bottom-up synthesis of GQDs was reported by Müllen group, based on the stepwise organic synthesis of dendritic polyphenylenes (DPPs) followed by dehydrogenation.[12] Such method can produce monodispersed GQDs with precisely defined molecular structure and size (hence properties). However, it is difficult, tedious, expensive, and of low production yield. And the resulting GQDs prone to π–π stacking because lack of functional groups. We here focus on the bottom-up methods that are realized by the fusion of organic molecules under thermal[13]/hydrothermal[14]/solvothermal[15] conditions or carbonization of organic precursors. In comparison, usually top-down methods can utilize cheap bulk carbon materials as precursors and can be applied to any graphitized materials. But they often have relatively low production yield and require longer reaction time and not easily disposable strong oxidants. In general, bottom-up methods offer relatively high yield and the convenience to introduce heteroatom doping during synthesis.

sections.heading: 2.1. Top-Down Methods
sections.text:
Oxidative cleavage is most frequently used for GQD synthesis from larger graphitized carbon materials such as graphite,[8] carbon black,[16,17] carbon fiber,[18,19] graphene,[20] or graphene oxide (GO).[21–23] Sometimes GQDs derived from GO sheets are called graphene oxide QD[24–27] or reduced graphene
oxide QD.[10] To avoid confusion, we simply call them GQDs here.
Strong acids are often used as the oxidants. Among all the precursors, coal is the cheapest. Comparing to graphite (Figure 2a),[8] coal can be more easily cleaved because it contains nanosized graphitized carbon domains weakly linked by amorphous carbon (Figure 2b).[28] Mixture of highly concentrated nitric and sulfuric acids was used in the original report. But the difficulty to remove sulfuric acid increases the synthesis cost. In principle, nitric acid alone should also work. Carbon black that is a cheap paracrystalline carbon can also be more easily cleaved by acids comparing to graphite.[17] Using oxidative cleavage, coal and carbon black are more promising than others for large-scale industrial production. Nonacid oxidants (e.g., oxone[29] and H2O2[30]), which are free radical initiators, have also been used to exfoliate GQDs (Figure 2c).[31] Comparing to strong acids, these oxidants are less environmentally hazardous. It is noteworthy that oxidatively exfoliated GQDs unavoidably bear abundant oxygenated groups (mainly, COOH, OH, COC). The induced oxygenated species and their ratio depend on the used oxidants.

Although 3D graphene gives extremely high efficiency and throughput, it and CNT are expensive precursors. Therefore, electrochemical cutting of graphite is more promising for low-cost and high-quality production of GQDs.
Alternative to oxidative cutting, reductive agents (e.g., hydrazine,[9,37] alkyl amines,[38] ammonia,[39,40] and DMF[41]) cleave oxidized carbon precursors into GQDs by breaking the CO bond in epoxy groups (Figure 2d).[41] Reductive cleavage introduces nitrogen-containing chemical groups and decreases oxygenated groups. The efficiency and the resulting GQD size depend on the abundance of epoxy groups on the precursors. Recently, it has been shown that GO sheets can be reduced and fragmented into GQDs in supercritical water under hydrothermal condition.[23,42] This synthesis is completely green and produces GQDs with low amount of oxygenated groups. But the production yield of this method is not reported. Physical cleavage
using grinding plus ultrasonication (Figure 2e)[10,43] or strong shear force in the microfluidizer[44] has also been reported. The thus produced GQDs have low presence of chemical groups and defects.

sections.heading: 2.2. Bottom-Up Methods
sections.text:
It has been demonstrated that methylbenzene and hexabromobenzene can fuse into GQDs free of chemical moieties using Na as the catalyst (Figure 2f).[45] But the synthesis requires extreme caution because Na is super-reactive and methylbenzene is carcinogenic. And undesirably graphene nanoribbon is also simultaneously produced. Citric acid has been used to hydrothermally produce GQDs.[46,47] Forming intermolecular hydrogen bonds and subsequent dehydration reaction generate the sp2 carbon network (Figure 2g). Note that, when the reaction time is prolonged, CDs instead of GQDs are produced.[48] It has been shown that the fusion of norepinephrine molecules

In a recent study, salicylic acid was used as the precursor which become aromatic radical under UV irradiation and then fuses into GQDs.[50] Under high temperature and inert atmosphere, many organic molecules or materials can be carbonized into graphitized materials for subsequent exfoliation of GQDs.[51]

sections.heading: 3. Property Control
sections.text: Owing to the small size, the electronic, optical, and catalytic properties of GQDs are highly influenced by various factors including size, functional groups, and dopants. Precisely tailoring these factors are the key to obtain GQDs with welldefined characteristics and therefore ensure their effective uses.

sections.heading: 3.1. GQD Size
sections.text: The bandgap of GQD is size-dependent (Figure 3a).[53] GQD size may be controlled by reaction time, temperature (Figure 3b),[54] and reactant concentration (Figure 3c).[38] GQD syntheses, particularly by top-down methods, usually produce GQDs with a wide range of size distribution. Such inhomogeneity leads to excitation-dependent photoluminescence spectrum.[55] The fractionation of GQDs with different sizes can be achieved using ultrafiltration through membranes with defined pore sizes[53] or using gel electrophoresis.[56] Larger size leads to smaller bandgap, hence longer fluorescence emission wavelength.[4]

sections.heading: 3.2. Oxidization
sections.text: Creating oxygenated groups on GQDs redshifts photoluminescence (PL) by introducing intermediate n orbital (Figure 3d),[10] but at the same time compromises PL quantum yield by acting as nonradiative centers.[39,57] On the contrary, removing the oxygenated groups using reductive agents blueshifts PL and increases QY, but at the same time sacrifices GQD dispersibility. The abundance of oxygenated group can be controlled by varying oxidative cutting time, strength of the oxidant, or postsynthesis reduction,[10,58] while the composition of oxygenated species is dictated by the specific oxidants or reductants used for synthesis. Different oxygenated species provide different functionalities. CO and COOH groups on GQD act together as peroxidase mimics,[59] while COOH and SO3H groups can serve as acid catalysts for many reactions.[60,61]

sections.heading: 3.3. Heteroatom Doping
sections.text:
Doped heteroatoms endow GQDs with altered electronic bandgap structures[62] and catalytic abilities.[63] Heteroatom doping can be realized through postsynthesis processes, for instances, N-doping by heating GQDs under ammonia gas or hydrothermally treating GQDs in ammonia solution.[24–26,64] N-doping narrows the bandgap (hence widens the light adsorption, as shown in Figure 3e) and prolongs the PL lifetime (because of suppression of charge recombination).[25,65] Hydrothermal treating GQDs with NaHSe produces orange-fluorescent
Se-doped GQDs with a high QY of 29%.[66] But the efficiency of postsynthesis doping is poor.
Doping during the synthesis usually gives higher efficiency. Heteroatom doping can be realized during topdown cutting synthesis via introducing heteroatom source or directly using dopant-containing oxidant or reductant.[67] A N,F- and S-codoped GQD has been prepared by ultrasonicating and microwaving CNTs in ionic liquid 1-methyl1-propylpiperidiniumbis(trifluoro-methylsulfonyl)imide.[68] Interestingly, doping greatly improved PL quantum yield. Cutting GO by boric acid vapor and ammonia gas in a tube furnace at high temperature produces B,N-codoped GQDs with good catalytic ability for oxygen reduction.[69] Electrochemically cutting graphite in electrolyte with P-containing sodium phytate gives P-doped GQDs.[70] P-doping confers GQD with the good ability to scavenge free radicals. Alternatively, cleaving heteroatom-containing graphitized precursors directly produces doped GQDs. For example, cutting fluorinated graphene by mixed sulfuric and nitric acids under ultrasonication forms F-doped GQDs with upconversion PL.[71] Cutting polythiophene by NaOH under hydrothermal condition produces S-doped GQDs that are capable of efficient generation of singlet oxygen, deep red emission (680 nm), and strong light absorption.[72] An S-doped GQD has been prepared by hydrothermal treatment of poly (3-alkylthiophenes) (P3ATs), which exhibits deep red emission up to 700 nm.[73] Moreover, the emission peak of such S-GQDs can be modulated by changing the alkyl chain length of P3ATs.
Heteroatom doping can be readily introduced during bottom-up synthesis using dopant-containing organic precursors or adding dopant source.[74–80] Comparing to other doping methods, it is relatively easier to dope on the basal carbon lattice. For example, the fusion of N-containing norepinephrine in water under microwave irradiation gives N-doped GQDs, while N,S-codoped GQDs are obtained in S-containing DMSO.[49] Based on the fusion of 1,3,6-trinitropyrene precursor, N,S-codoped GQDs are obtained under DMF-based solvothermal condition in the presence of thiourea and NaOH,[15] while S-doped GQDs are produced under hydrothermal condition in the presence of 3-mercaptopropionic acid.[75]
Based on molecular condensation of citric acid molecules, N-doped GQDs are yielded in the presence of N-containing tris(hydroxymethyl)aminomethane[76] and N,S-doped GQDs are produced in the presence of N,S-containing l-cysteine.[78] B-doped GQDs have been synthesized under solvothermal condition in the presence of 4-vinylphenylboronic acid and boric acid.[80] Such B-GQDs show strong magnetic resonance and upconversion PL property. In a recent work, S-doped GQDs have been synthesized from organic molecules from durian flesh.[81] Increasing reaction temperature leads to higher doping percentage and consequently longer emission wavelength (from blue to orange).

sections.heading: 3.4. Surface/Edge Functionalization
sections.text:
Surface passivation (e.g., by PEG) to block traps or defects leads to QY increase.[82] PEG (or PEI) functionalization also redshifts PL because of bandgap narrowing, resulting from the charge transfer from the functional groups to GQD.[83]

Inspired by the previous studies,[84,85] Yan et al. recently propose two distinct strategies to systematically and continuously narrow down the electronic bandgap of GQDs with an initial wider bandgap (Figure 3f).[86] Because the bandgap of pristine GQD (separation between π and π* orbitals) is inversely proportional to the size of sp2 domain, bandgap narrowing is
Adv. Mater. 2019, 1808283
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1808283 (7 of 22)
realized via conjugating GQDs with polyaromatic molecules to enlarge the π-conjugated sp2-carbon network. The larger the conjugated polyaromatic molecules the narrower the resulting GQD bandgap (hence the longer the PL emission wavelength). It may be speculated that this strategy will not work as well for CDs or other QDs because their bandgaps are less sensitive to quantum confinement. Alternatively, bandgap narrowing is achieved by introducing an intermediate n-orbital between π and π* orbitals upon grafting with electron-donating chemical groups. The stronger the electrondonating ability of the chemical groups the narrower the resulting GQD bandgap.

sections.heading: 4.1. Energy Conversion and Storage
sections.text: GQDs promise a wide range of applications in energy conversion and storage because of their large surface area, abundant active sites, capability to facilitate charge transfer and transport, tunable optical properties, and ability to intimately integrate with other nanomaterials.

sections.heading: 4.1.1. Photovoltaics
sections.text:
GQDs have served as the sensitizers in GQD/semiconductor solar cells,[87–93] electron/hole transport layer materials in organic or perovskite solar cells,[84,94,95] and the active layer additive in donor/acceptor blends for dye-sensitized solar cells.[96–98] In the GQD/semiconductor heterojunction based solar cell (Figure 4a), GQDs favor carrier separation,[87,88] light absorption,[89,90] charge carrier extraction,[91] and downconversion property (Figure 4b).[92,93,99] A solar cell fabricated by kinetic spray of GQDs onto crystalline Si shows a high power conversion efficiency of 15.3% partly because a UV photon absorbed by GQD can generate two electrons at the heterojunction (Figure 4c).[89] For organic or perovskite solar cells, GQDs with electron-donating (or electron-withdrawing) functional groups serve well in the electron[84] (or hole[94]) extraction layer by decreasing (or increasing) the work function (Figure 4d).[91] Being sandwiched between perovskite and TiO2 cathode, the electron-donating phenylenediamine-functionalized GQDs with narrow bandgap enhance electron extraction, and consequently increase the power conversion efficiency by 15.1% compared to the solar cell without GQDs (Figure 4e).[84] When being coated between the polymer active layer and the ITO

anode, the electron-withdrawing COOH-functionalized GQDs enhance hole extraction, and thus improve the power conversion efficiency by 50%.[94] In dye-sensitized solar cells, GQDs promote light absorption,[96] charge separation,[97] and exciton dissociation (Figure 4f).[98] When GQDs being bonded into the active layer by PEG, P3HT as the donor, and PCBM as the acceptor, the solar cell exhibits 36% efficiency improvement compared with the solar cell without GQDs.[98]

sections.heading: 4.1.2. Light-Emitting Diodes
sections.text:
In light-emitting diodes (LEDs), GQDs can serve as the electroluminescent phosphor (Figure 5a,b),[8,100–102] dopant in organic light emitter,[38] bandgap tuner,[37] or color converter.[103,104] As the electroluminescent phosphor, octadecylamine-functionalized GQD (ODA-GQD)-based LED achieves the highest current (6.51 cd A−1) and external quantum efficiency (2.67%) among the reported GQD-based LEDs because ODA-GQDs reduce
the hole barrier and improve the hole injection efficiency from anode to active layer.[102] As the dopant in organic light emitter, GQDs with narrower bandgap offer brighter white electroluminescence because narrow bandgap favors low-energy emission and reduces exciton lifetime (Figure 5c,d).[38] As the bandgap tuner in active layer, GQDs functionalized with electron-donating aniline derivatives exhibit redshifted electroluminescence because of bandgap narrowing, and consequently improve color purity (Figure 5e).[37] As the color converter, amino-functionalized GQDs casted on blue LED chip convert blue light to white (Figure 5f).[104]

sections.heading: 4.1.3. Photodetectors
sections.text:
Taking advantage of the good light adsorption of GQDs, they have been used as photosensitizers in photodetectors (Figure 6a).[105,106] Large-bandgap GQDs have been used to form heterostructure for highly selective UV detection

(Figure 6b).[107–109] The excellent responsivity of 36 A W−1, detectivity of 1.3 × 1012 Hz1/2 W−1, and ultrasensitive response of 7.0 mA cm−2 under weak UV light (0.07 mW cm−2) have been achieved by GQD decorated ZnO nanorods (Figure 6c).[109] The authors also demonstrate that GQDs are superior to carbon dots due to their lower trap-state density and the better ability to lower the energy barrier. GQD and graphene hybrid supported on lead zirconate titanate (PZT) makes a stable, rapid, and ultrasensitive (4.06 × 109 A W−1) photodetector for broadband light detection.[110] The built-in electric field induced by PZT favors separation of electron–hole pairs and subsequent hole transfer to the underlying graphene channel. Narrowbandgap GQDs have been used to widen the light adsorption range. Diaminonaphthalene-functionalized GQDs with much reduced bandgap (1.3 eV) have been hybridized with graphene and coated on boron nitride sheets to provide photodetection from UV to infrared (Figure 6d).[111] Polymer (e.g., PEI[105] and PANI[112]) functionalization induces multiple trap states on GQD which favor the realization of broadband photodetector.

sections.heading: 4.1.4. Thermoelectric Devices
sections.text:
In thermoelectric devices, GQDs have been employed to restrict thermal conductivity[113] and the size of thermoelectric nanocrystals by acting as the capping agent.[114] Specifically, GQDs have been utilized as the ligand exchanger to stabilize PbTe, PbSe, PbS, and CdSe nanoparticles, preventing their overgrowth and aggregation.[114] GQDs preserve quantum confinement of the nanocrystals and promote energy filtering of carriers. The device achieves the figure of merit (ZT) of 0.46 at 650 K. GQDs/Bi2Te3 hybrid nanosheets show reduced thermal conductivity than Bi2Te3 alone because GQDs with oxygenated groups increase the interface coulomb barriers and power factor.[113] With GQD

sections.heading: 4.1.5. Supercapacitors
sections.text:
GQDs have been used for supercapacitors because of their large specific surface area (Figure 7a)[115] and high pseudocapacitance originated from edges,[116] defects,[117] functional groups,[118] and dopants (Figure 7b).[119,120] N-doped GQDs[121] and amine-functionalized GQDs[122] have achieved high specific capacitance of 509 and 595 F g−1, respectively. It has also been demonstrated that decoration of GQDs can largely enhance the capacitance of 3D graphene (Figure 7c).[123] A flexible and transparent GQD–graphene micro-supercapacitor shows specific capacitance of 9.09 µF cm−2 with high stability.[124] Hybridized GQD–polyaniline nanotubes exhibit a high specific capacitance of 1044 F g−1 due to the large surface area and conductivity.[125] A heterostructure electrode is fabricated by growing GQDs on MnO2 nanosheets using chemical vapor deposition,
with good interface bonding due to the formation of MnOC bonds (Figure 7d).[116] GQDs extend the potential window to 1.3 V because of built-in electric field resulting from the different work functions of the two materials. The specific capacitance reaches 1170 F g−1 at a scan rate of 5 mV s−1, which is the highest among all GQD-based supercapacitors.

sections.heading: 4.1.6. Rechargeable Batteries
sections.text:
In Li or Na ion batteries, GQDs can help to relieve the volume expansion,[126] accelerate Li+/Na+ diffusion,[127,128] and electron transfer,[129,130] enhance the interfacial double layer,[131,132] and improve electrochemical properties.[126,129,131,133] GQDs have been used as the surface sensitizer on VO2/graphene arrays to enhance electrochemical performance, whereby enabling a high Li-battery capacity (>420 mAh g−1) and Na-battery capacity (306 mAh g−1) at 18 A g−1 with high stability (Figure 8a).[131] GQDs can expand interlayer distance between MoS2 layers and hence accelerate electrochemical kinetics with high stability.[126]

GQDs/MoS2 exhibits high discharge capacity of 820 mAh g−1 at 2 A g−1, which is 2.5 times higher than the electrode made of MoS2 only. Coating of phenylalanine-functionalized GQDs on Si electrode accelerates electron transfer and Li+ diffusion, achieving a high capacity of 1820 mAh g−1 at 1A g−1.[129] Because GQDs inhibit ion-solvent clustering and immobilize PF6¯ anions to enhance the Li+ diffusion and conductivity, the LiFePO4 battery based on GQD modified gel polymer electrolyte delivers a high capacity of 155 mAh g−1 at 0.1 C and exhibits a long cycle life up to 500 cycles at 5 C.[127] GQDs can also enhance Li+ diffusion by immobilizing Sn2− in a lithium– sulfur battery (Figure 8b).[128]

sections.heading: 4.2. Catalysis
sections.text: Chemical groups and dopants confer GQDs with intrinsic catalytic properties. They can also improve the performance of many catalysts through bandgap alignment, synergic cooperation, morphology modulation, light adsorption enhancement, or promotion of charge transfer. Owing to their chemical inertness, GQDs often can enhance the stability of other catalysts. Because GQDs are highly dispersible, they may act as quasihomogeneous catalysts providing both high catalytic efficiency and possibility to be recycled, in other words, combining the merits of homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysts.

sections.heading: 4.2.1. Photocatalysis
sections.text:
Making use of fully accessible surface, tunable bandgap structure, good light absorption, high dispersibility, excellent
photostability, and the ability to form heterojunction with other nanomaterials, GQDs have been employed as photocatalysts for H2 evolution,[24–26,86,134–138] CO2 reduction,[86,139,140] and pollutants degradation.[74,79,141–146] GQDs are desirable photocatalysts because their typical bandgaps (1.8–2.4 eV) are large enough to drive redox reactions and yet not too large to ensure broad light adsorption. And light adsorption range and exciton separation may be enhanced by forming heterojunctions or hybrids with other light harvesting nanomaterials.
The electron-donating moieties (dopants such as N and S or chemical groups such as NH2) and electron-withdrawing moieties (chemical groups such as COOH) on a GQD induce n- and p-type conductivity respectively, while the basal carbon network acts as Ohmic contact between them. This can be regarded as the unique intramolecular Z-scheme structure (Figure 9a)[86] or intramolecular p–n-type photochemical diode.[24] Such structure favors separation of photogenerated electron–hole pairs and enables simultaneous occurrence of oxidation reaction at n-type domains and reduction reaction at p-type domains. A GQD with engineered narrow bandgap (thus enhanced light adsorption) and intramolecular Z-scheme has been used for efficient CO2 reduction and H2 evolution.[86] A N-doped GQD with oxygenated groups (Figure 9b)[25] and a S-doped GQD with oxygenated groups[137] have also shown good performance in H2 evolution. GQDs have been hybridized with other nanomaterials (TiO2,[134] CdS,[136] ZnNb2O6/gC3N4[135]) for H2 evolution, serving as the light absorber or/ and electron acceptor in the heterojunction. For example, the heterojunction formed between S,N-codoped GQD and TiO2 exhibits an ultrahigh photocatalytic H2 evolution rate of 86 mmol gcat−1 h−1.[138]

A chromophore-functionalized GQD coupled with formate dehydrogenase shows high formic acid formation rate of 99.48 µmol h−1 from CO2 reduction because such photocatalyst– biocatalyst integrated system can utilize light energy from UV to NIR.[139] Hybridization of N-doped GQDs with perovskite nanocubes (nitrogen and oxygen vacancy confined in sodium tantalite, Vo-NaTaON) provides excellent photoreduction rates of CO2 toward CO and CH4 at 43 and 14 µmol gcat−1 h−1 respectively, due to enhanced light absorption and charge separation (Figure 9c).[140]
Doped GQDs have been used as the photocatalysts for organic synthesis too. For example, a N,S-codoped GQD displays high photocatalytic performance in aerobic oxidative coupling of various amines (100% conversion) owing to broad light adsorption, increased electron-rich Fermi level, and prolonged lifetime of the excited singlet state to convert oxygen to superoxide.[49] A hybrid of N,S-codoped GQD and Fe(III) tetra(4-sulfonatophenyl)porphyrins shows good performance in selective photo-oxidation of alcohols to desired carbonyl compounds attributable to enhanced light absorption, charge separation and oxygen activation.[147]
GQDs have been utilized for photocatalytic degradation of pollutants, making use of their light adsorption and ability to form heterojunction (e.g., with zinc porphyrin,[141] TiO2,[79,142] Bi2MoO6,[144] C3N4,[145,146] MnNb2O6,[74] or N-Bi2O2CO3[148] as shown in Figure 9d) or form Z-scheme structure (e.g., with ZnO[143]). For instance, GQD–zinc porphyrin heterojunction with improved separation of electron–hole pairs promotes generation of superoxide anion radical or H2O2 for faster degradation of methylene blue (MB).[141] Similarly, GQD/C3N4 heterojunction can produce more superoxide anion radical and holes for better photocatalytic degradation of rhodamine B (RhB) and tetracycline (TC) (Figure 9e).[145]

sections.heading: 4.2.2. Electrocatalysis
sections.text:
GQDs are instrumental for electrocatalytic reactions, such as oxygen reduction (ORR),[45,149–156] oxygen evolution (OER),[157–160] hydrogen evolution (HER)[19,161–163] and CO2 reduction[164–166] reactions. B,N-GQDs[153] and N-GQDs[154] have been employed

© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1808283 (13 of 22)
as ORR catalysts based on their catalytically active dopant sites. But usually, GQDs are hybridized with other nanomaterials such as graphene,[45,151,152] C3N4,[149] carbon nanotubes,[150] and reduced graphene oxide (rGO)[155,156] to realize synergistic effects. Because of abundant active sites (edges, defects, and interfaces) and fast charge transfer between GQDs and graphene nanoribbons (GNRs), GQD–GNR hybrid demonstrates ultrahigh performance for ORR with high selectivity and stability, as well as higher limiting current density and lower overpotential than those of Pt.[45] Hybrid of B, N-GQD and graphene combines the catalytic abilities of the former and the high conductivity of the latter, leading to excellent ORR performance far superior to commercial Pt/C.[152] MoS2-rGO 3D framework decorated with N-GQDs has been used for direct methanol fuel cells with excellent ORR performance, stability and methanol tolerance.[156]
N-GQDs are good electrocatalysts for OER because N dopants induce charge redistribution through π–π delocalization to reduce *OOH thermodynamic energy barrier.[160] But often, GQDs are hybridized with nanomaterials such as NiCo2P2,[157] Ni3S2,[158] and Co3O4[159] to improve the performance.[160] It has recently been demonstrated that GQDs are able to engineer nanocatalysts into nanosheet morphology because of their atomically thin planar structure (Figure 9f).[5] Specifically, GQDs greatly boost both OER and HER performance of NiCo2P2 by controlling catalyst morphology, enhancing charge transfer and transport, and improving the catalytic kinetics.[157] GQDs have also been used to improve the HER performance of MoS2,[19,161] Ni3S2,[162] and CoP.[163] GQD–MoS2 composite can achieve high HER activity with low onset potential and good stability because GQDs reduce the bandgap toward zero and enhance charge transfer.[19] Depositing GQDs on CoP nanoparticles grown on graphene (GQDs/CoP/G) gives nearly 100% Faradaic efficiency in HER, because of increased active surface area, promoted conductivity and carrier mobility.[163]
N-doped GQDs can electrocatalyze CO2 reduction into hydrocarbons and oxygenates at high current density, good Faradaic efficiency (90%) and low overpotential, with selective conversion (45%) toward ethylene and ethanol.[164] In contrast, undoped GQDs and N-doped rGOs mainly produce CO and HCOO− through distinct reaction routes, testifying the importance of N-doping and the superiority of GQD to rGO. DFT calculations show that N dopants on a GQD electrochemically convert CO2 into CH4, C2H4, C2H5OH, HCOO− and CO at ←0.6 V.[165] N dopants also facilitate adsorption of reaction intermediate (*COOH) whereby promoting reduction of CO2 to CO. Desirably, the presence of water favors the reaction selectivity toward CH4. A well-defined GQD–rhenium complex as a molecular catalyst exhibits a ultralow overpotential (−0.48 V vs NHE) for CO2 reduction to CO (Figure 9g).[166] N-GQDs decorated Bi2O3 nanosheets show ≈100% Faraday efficiency for reduction of CO2 to formate at an overpotential of 0.7 V, owing to the enhanced adsorption ability of CO2 by N-GQDs.[167]
GQDs are also useful for electrocatalytic organic synthesis and fuel cells. As an example, metal/GQD composites prepared through layer-by-layer assembly exhibit efficient and versatile catalytic capability in selective conversion of aromatic nitro compounds, methanol electro-oxidation and water splitting, attributable to the increased charge transfer and synergistic
interaction between metal (Au, Ag, and Pt) nanocrystals and GQDs.[168]

sections.heading: 4.2.3. Photoelectrocatalysis
sections.text: GQDs have been used as photosensitizer,[169,170] electron donor,[171] or hole extractor[171,172] for photoelectrochemical reactions. GQDs modified ZnO nanowires functionalized with 3-aminopropyltriethoxysilane (GQDs@APTES-ZnO NWs) can work as photoanode for photoelectrochemical water splitting with much increased efficiency, owing to GQD-enhanced light absorption and charge separation.[169] As a chemically inert carbon material, GQD improves the stability of CdSe QDsensitized photoanode.[171] At the same time, as the hole extractor and electron donor, it accelerates charge transfer kinetics for photoelectrochemical degradation of MB and hydrogen evolution.

sections.heading: 4.2.4. Chemical Catalysis
sections.text:
The chemical groups on a GQD are able to catalyze chemical reactions. It has been recently demonstrated that GQDs bearing SO3H and COOH groups can serve as the highly effective and recyclable quasihomogeneous acid catalyst for one-pot selective conversion of carbohydrates into 5-hydroxymethylfurfural.[60] The high efficiency is partly attributable to the cooperation between different functional groups on GQDs. It is conceivable that GQDs with various chemical groups, dopants, or decorated nanocatalysts (e.g., Pt nanoparticles) shall be able to catalyze more complex reactions or multi-step reactions at one site.
GQDs can act as the peroxidase mimics to convert H2O2 into hydroxyl radicals. It has been shown that CO groups on GQD are the catalytic sites while OCO groups are the substrate-binding sites.[59] Utilizing such enzymatic activity and its ability to tightly bind with aromatic alcohols via π–π interaction, Au/GQD nanoparticles have shown high performance in oxidizing veratryl alcohol to veratryl aldehyde or veratric acid, in the presence of H2O2.[173]

sections.heading: 4.3. Flexible Devices
sections.text: Considering their small size and exceptional mechanical properties (e.g., both high strength and flexibility), GQDs are naturally suitable for flexible devices. Given their high dispersibility, they are particularly attractive for printable flexible devices.

sections.heading: 4.3.1. Flexible Memory Devices
sections.text:
GQDs are able to function as the charge-trap material in memory devices, owing to their multiple energy levels, edge states and quantum confinement effect.[174–176] Or they can be used as resistive switching material based on the resonant electron tunneling effect.[177] GQDs coated between SiO2 layers work as the charge traps for memory capacitor.[174] The memory window, program and erase speed, durability and data retention

can be modulated by GQD size. When GQDs are used as charge trapping medium for organic nanofloating gate memory, highly reversible switching performance with the on/off current ratio more than 106, long retention time over 104 s and cycle endurance >100 have been achieved.[175] The GQD layer is able to trap charges as high as 7.2 × 1012 cm−2.

sections.heading: 4.3.2. Flexible Electrochromic Devices
sections.text: GQDs have been applied in flexible electrochromic devices, serving as electron transfer medium to replace electrolyte solution. A electrolyte-free flexible electrochromic device using the composite of GQD and methyl viologen displays a stable switching performance, high endurance and stability.[178]

sections.heading: 4.4. Biomedical Applications
sections.text: It is not surprising that GQDs are highly biocompatible to carbon-based life on earth. And comparing to other nanomaterials or their nanocarbon cousins, GQDs have much fast renal clearance and biodegradation rate due to their small sizes. Their unique optical, electrochemical, and physicochemical properties enable many theranostic applications. Applications of GQD-based sensors for monitoring food safety are also discussed in this section.

sections.heading: 4.4.1. Cellular and In Vivo Imaging
sections.text:
Because of photobleaching, conventional organic fluorophores do not allow long-term imaging. To tackle this issue, semiconductor quantum dots have been widely used. However, being much bigger than a biomolecule, semiconductor QDs may alter the dynamics (functions) of the target and bind with multiple targets to create artificial cluster. Besides, they can be toxic due to leaching of heavy metal ions. In comparison, GQDs offer unique advantages for molecular imaging in cells owing to the unique combination of several key merits, including good photostability, molecular size, biocompatibility, ease to be functionalized, tunable PL properties, good dispersibility, and chemical stability.[2]
Since the first demonstration of GQD for molecular (insulin receptor) imaging and dynamic tracking in live cells,[179] there are several new developments worthy to be highlighted. Instead of conjugating GQDs with proteins or other recognition moieties, Chen et al. for the first time functionalize GQD with monosaccharaides to reveal the distribution and trafficking of carbohydrate receptors on cells.[180] Recently, Li et al. have devised a reversible fluorescence probe sensitive to both oxidants and reductants and used such GQD probe for real-time monitoring of dynamic change in intracellular redox state in response to oxidative or reductive stress (Figure 10a).[181] This is the first demonstration of using GQDs to examine a cellular dynamic activity. Later, the same authors demonstrated a GQDbased fluorescence probe for real-time monitoring of triggered dynamic change of the intracellular H2S level in live cells.[182] Unlike most GQD-based probes, this is a fluorescence turn-on probe, functionalized with electron-withdrawing dinitrophenyl
groups which quench GQD PL through photoinduced electron transfer and can be specifically cleaved by H2S to allow recovery of GQD PL.
GQDs that emit long wavelengths or be excited by long wavelengths residing within the “biological transparent windows” (650–950 and 1000–1350 nm) are particularly attractive for in vivo imaging. Red fluorescence GQDs can be made by doping heteroatoms to narrow the bandgap. For examples, a S,N-codoped GQD emitting at 640 nm has been used for cellular imaging (Figure 10b)[138] and a S-doped GQD emitting at 680 nm has been used for in vivo imaging in mice (Figure 10c).[72] Another 680 nm emitting GQD prepared from a mango leaf has been used for cell imaging.[183] Heteroatom doping may confer GQDs with extraordinary PL properties. A N,P-codoped GQD exhibits strong two-photon upconversion property.[52] A B-doped GQD which has two-photon upconversion and magnetic property has been employed for both NIR and MRI imaging (Figure 10d).[80] The two-photon upconversion property provides the possibility for in vivo deep-tissue imaging. A N-doped GQD has been employed for two-photon imaging in mice with 800 nm excitation.[184] In another example, N-doped GQD conjugate has been utilized to reveal endogenous H2O2 level in mice based on quenching of two-photon PL emission under 740 nm excitation.[185] GQDs functionalized with peptide[186] or alkylamines[187] also show upconversion PL for NIR excited imaging.

sections.heading: 4.4.2. Photoluminescence Sensing
sections.text:
Owing to their small size, PL of GQDs is extremely sensitive to minute environmental perturbation and they can intimately interact with small molecules. Therefore, GQD-based luminescence sensors often provide much improved sensitivity.[2] Various sensors have been developed making use of the fact that PL of molecularly sized GQDs is particularly sensitive to aggregation-induced PL quenching,[188,189] fluorescence resonance energy transfer (FRET),[190] photon-induced electron transfer,[181,191] or PL increase in presence of turn-on chromoionophore.[192] For example, Li et al. have demonstrated specific fluorometric assay of multiple metabolites in a blood droplet using tyramine-functionalized GQDs (Figure 11a).[189] In this system, GQD acts not only as fluorescence reporter but also as hydrogen peroxidase mimic which produces free radicals from enzymatically generated H2O2 to induce GQD crosslinking (hence aggregation). Also based on GQD aggregation induced PL quenching, Shen et al. have demonstrated highly luminescent N,S-codoped GQDs for parallel detection of Fe3+, Cu2+ and Ag+ ions with low detection limits because of the coordination reaction between these ions and the heteroatoms/ functional groups on GQDs (Figure 11b).[15] GQD-based PL sensors have been used to detect food poisoning, including bacteria,[193] insecticides,[194] heavy metal ions,[195] food packaging materials.[196] For example, a turn-on fluorescence sensor based on N- and S-codoped GQDs has been used to detect ethion (insecticide) in food samples.[197] Firstly GQD PL is quenched by Hg2+ due to charge transfer through HgS bonds. In the presence of ethion, GQD PL recovers because Hg2+ is deprived from GQD by this S-containing small molecule.

sections.heading: 4.4.3. Electrochemiluminescence (ECL) Sensing
sections.text: Generally, ECL sensing is based on excitation of GQDs by the radicals electrochemically derived at the electrode surface from a coreactant (Figure 11c).[21] When charge transfer between GQDs and radicals is interrupted by the targeted analytes, ECL is quenched in a dose-dependent manner. Using cathodic ECL and S2O82− as the coreactant, sensitive detection of metal ion,[21,198] protein[199] and nucleic acids (Figure 11d)[200,201] has been demonstrated. Using anodic ECL and H2O2 as the coreactant, pH[202,203] and Co2+ ion[203] are detected with high sensitivity.

sections.heading: 4.4.4. Electrochemical Sensing
sections.text:
Using GQD’s ability to specifically and intimately interact with small analytes (via π–π interaction or interaction with functional moieties or dopants on GQDs), facilitate charge transfer, and catalyze redox species, they have been used for electrochemical detection of metal ions,[204,205] dopamine,[205,206] epinephrine,[207] H2O2,[208] glutathione,[66] alkaline phosphatase,[209]
endogenous arachidonic acid,[210] pesticide,[211] and therapeutic drugs.[212] A novel electrochemical sensing platform based on nanochannel confined GQDs has recently been demonstrated (Figure 11e),[205] where GQD serves as the signal recognition element through specific interaction with the analytes (coordination with metal ions by its functional groups or dopants, π–π interaction with dopamine) and as the signal enhancer through electrostatic enrichment of the analytes and facilitation of charge transfer. Meanwhile, the vertically aligned nanochannel array prevents nonspecific access to the electrode by numerous molecules in the complex fluid samples. This sensor is able to detect heavy metal ions with ultralow detection limits (9.8 × 10−12 m for Hg2+, 8.3 × 10−12 m for Cu2+, and 4.3 × 10−9 m for Cd2+) in the complex practical samples (serum and seafoods) without the need of tedious pretreatments.

sections.heading: 4.4.5. Photoelectrochemical Sensing
sections.text:
Photoelectrochemical sensing is based on the enhancement of photocurrent when the interaction between the analyte and the photoresponsive material consumes photogenerated

sections.heading: 4.4.6. Photothermal and Photodynamic Therapy
sections.text:
As a new kind of photothermal and photodynamic therapy agent, GQD exhibits some unique advantages such as good biocompatibility, excellent dispersibility, broad light absorption, good photostability, fast body clearance, ease to be degraded by enzymes, and the ability to produce radicals.[42,216] A N-GQD with good photothermal conversion efficiency of 62.53% has been reported.[217] IR780 is an excellent NIR photothermal agent, but suffers from poor solubility. Folic acid functionalized
GQDs can hybridize with IR780 through π–π stacking and the hybrid shows excellent dispersibility and much enhanced photothermal conversion efficiency of 87.9% due to synergistic effects (Figure 12a).[218]
GQDs have been used for photodynamic therapy (Figure 12b)[219] and killing bacteria[220] because they can produce reactive oxygen species (ROS) under light irradiation.[221] A COOH-bearing GQD demonstrates good photodynamic property under NIR two-photon excitation, promising for deep tissue cancer therapy.[222] It has been shown that N-doping enhances GQD’s ability to generate singlet oxygen and superoxide radical anions.[223] And such N-doped GQD has been employed for in vivo cancer therapy under NIR twophoton excitation. Ge et al. reported a N,S-doped GQD which has an excellent 1O2 quantum yield of 1.3 owing to a multistate sensitization mechanism under visible light illumination.[72] In vivo and in vitro studies demonstrate its potential for treating skin cancers.

sections.heading: 4.4.7. Other Therapeutic Applications
sections.text: GQDs conjugated with an antiretroviral agent (CHI499) is able to suppress HIV based on inhibition of both the activity of reverse transcriptase and virus binding to the cells.[224] GQDs have also show potential to treat Parkinson’s disease via inhibiting fibrillization of α-syn and directly disaggregating the mature fibrils.[225] Furthermore, GQDs can rescue neuronal death and synaptic loss, reduce Lewy body and Lewy neurite formation, ameliorate mitochondrial dysfunctions, and prevent neuron-to-neuron transmission of α-syn pathology provoked by α-syn preformed fibrils. For amyloidosis treatment, the electrostatic and π–π interactions between GQDs and islet amyloid polypeptide (IAPP) prevents the aggregation and toxicity of IAPP fibrils.[226]

sections.heading: 5. Current Challenges and Outlook
sections.text:
GQDs are flat 0D nanocarbon materials which could change the landscape in many fields of science and technology. Although the development is rapid, there are still issues to be addressed and challenges to be overcome. First of all, in order
to have a roadmap of GQD research, its unambiguous definition should be agreed upon by the community and its unique properties distinct to similarly structured nanomaterials should be recognized, otherwise confusions and inconsistencies will be resulted in the literature and GQD applications are not optimal. In addition, it should be kept in mind that owing to the large heterogeneity in composition, size, and shape, GQDs prepared by different methods cover a very wide range of chemicophysical properties. Therefore, a successful application based on one kind of GQD may not be feasible to another kind. An urgent need is to develop methods to synthesize GQDs with welldefined characteristics or to precisely engineer GQD properties or to differentially isolate different GQD populations so that better and more systematic characterization and understanding of GQDs as well as more effective applications can be achieved.
For imaging, display and fluorescence-based sensing, the disadvantage of GQD is the relatively low PL QY as compared to other fluorophores such as CDs, semiconductor QDs, and organic dyes. QY can be improved by removing or passivating the chemical moieties acting as the nonradiative recombination centers and introducing heteroatom doping. Some GQDs have QY > 30% which is high enough for most bioimaging purposes. Although it is unlikely GQD can be as bright as some of

its competitors (keeping in mind that GQD is very small), its other merits together warrant many unique applications.
GQD may be viewed as a complex giant π-conjugated molecule whose properties are influenced by many factors, such as, size, chemical groups, dopants, edge configurations, defects, and shape. Experimentally isolating their individual influence is challenging without being able to precisely control GQD composition and morphology, whereas theoretical studies can provide important insights.[62] Currently, little is known about the interplay between these factors (e.g., coexistence of both electron-donating and electron-withdrawing chemical groups and coexistence of different heteroatom dopants). These interplays shall bring new properties thus new application opportunities. In addition, heterojunctions formed between GQDs and other nanomaterials are not thoroughly studied although interesting phenomena have already been observed and more are highly anticipated. An interesting study shows that chirality can be introduced to a GQD by edge-functionalization of chiral molecules.[227] How chirality or distortion in general affects GQD properties deserves further investigation.
The current scope of GQD applications has already covered a wide range of topics. And it is still expanding, for examples, the recent use of GQDs as quasihomogeneous catalysts for chemical synthesis and conversion[60] and use of GQDs for flexible devices.[176,228] Just like other graphene materials, GQDs can be used to engineer and improve the properties of other functional nanomaterials.[5] Conceivably, in view of their high dispersibility and intrinsic amphiphilic properties, GQDs may serve as a new class of surfactants for many applications.
Currently, many applications of GQDs are not practically feasible because low-cost industrial-scale synthesis of GQDs has not been actually realized yet. But we predict that just like the current capability for mass-production of graphene materials, ton-scale production of GQDs are possible using either topdown or bottom-up strategies. Not only the synthesis but also purification should be scalable. On benchtop, ultrafiltration is often used for purification which is faster than also commonly used methods like dialysis and electrophoresis. But it is expensive and not feasible for large-scale production. In comparison, cross-flow ultrafiltration is suitable for industrial production and ensure constant throughput because of the absence of buildup on the membrane. On the other hand, massproduction is not a major hurdle to biomedical applications or some applications that only require a small amount of GQDs as the additives. In our opinion, GQD research is still young yet has a great potential if current challenges can be tackled and the unique combination of desirable merits of GQDs can be properly utilized.

In the literature, GQD and another kind of 0D carbon materials (carbon dot) are often not carefully distinguished. Here, we would like to stress that GQDs and carbon dots (CDs) differ in morphology and properties. CDs are spherical carbon particles. Some are completely amorphous sp3 carbon while some have a crystalline sp2 core encapsulated by an amorphous shell. Typically, the diameter of a CD is >3 nm, and CDs have a relatively wide X-ray diffraction (XRD) peak due to the presence of amorphous carbon. Also, unlike GQDs the completely amorphous CDs do not present crystalline lattice under high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM). Furthermore, the electronic bandgap structures of GQDs are largely influenced by quantum confinement effect[4] whereas CDs’ bandgap structures are dictated by the surface energy traps. Due to these differences, some methods or applications work well for one but may not work well for the other. Although GQDs and CDs share some similarities, here we exclusively focus on the former. 0D quantum dots can also be derived from other 2D materials (notably, transition metal dichalcogenides).[1] These 2D materials range from insulators (e.g., h-BN and HfS2), large bandgap semiconductors (e.g., C3N4, MoS2, and WS2), small bandgap semiconductors (e.g., black phosphorene), and metallike conductors (e.g., VSe2). In comparison to GQDs, QDs derived from these 2D materials have distinct intrinsic electronic structures, thickness, and other properties. Some of them can fluoresce in the visible light range for biomedical imaging (e.g., MoS2 QD), but they are not very stable and dispersible in aqueous solution, not easily to be functionalized, or has very low photoluminescence quantum yield (QY). Pristine GQD is rarely useful other than for electronic devices. And it cannot be easily synthesized and dispersed. In fact, it is chemical groups, functionalized groups, defects, dopants, and their coexistence that make GQDs interesting and versatile. But one may argue that the conductivity (an intrinsic merit of graphene) is lost due to these factors. This is indeed the case and some papers mistakenly claim that their device or electrode performance is benefited from the good conductivity of GQDs. The significant advances in the recent years are summarized with comparative and balanced discussion. The differences between GQDs and other nanomaterials, including their nanocarbon cousins, are emphasized, and the unique advantages of GQDs for specific applications are highlighted.
